comments.commentBody:
"Wage slaves" is only laughable if you aren't one of them.

Also, with the financial crash of 2008, none of the perpetrators were punished.
We have essentially legalized bank robbery.

And the real Welfare Queens are the Corporations. That, of course, is acceptable welfare.

The rich always find their flavor if corruption and larceny acceptable and good.
How surprising.

It is unbelievable to me that, knowing their body-cam is recording, these "law officers" have the audacity first to "lose it" and escalate a banal situation into violence during a traffic stop and second to lie about the circumstances of the arrest to defend their behavior. Thank god for cell phones and body cams. Think of all the innocent people of color who have been sacrificed to police violence before the advent of recording devices. Their families probably listened in stunned disbelief when they were told their law-abiding, peaceful, unarmed loved one died because the officer was in fear of his life when a gun was pulled on the cop, leading to justification of their loved one's death. This madness must stop. We are losing more young men of color in America to police violence than we are losing in violent Afghanistan. Madness.

In the recent spate of police killing civilians, from New York to Ohio, Missouri to South Carolina, tragedies in-between and now again in Ohio, the Police argue that the citizen acted improperly.  True or not, the fact remains that law enforcement are the professionals in these encounters, which means that the onus of conduct is upon them and arms are only a measure of last resort. Police also often initiate the contact, so they should be responsible for setting the most calm and non-confrontational tone possible.  If wearing the uniform is supposed to confer respect, those in it must also convey respect for others' lives.

You may not want to say it but, from my perspective, it certainly looks like it's open season on black men among police departments in the U.S. You write: "How little must an officer think of the person at the other end of the barrel to shoot him in the head when ... there appears to be no threat?" But is it just disregard for blacks in general that's on display here or is there something much more sinister going on?

This has got to stop. Whatever it takes.  if you see something, say something.  if you can, take a picture, or a movie.  If you can't, write it all down as soon as you can.  And if it comes to that, be prepared to put your body between that cop and his victim.

About the time I feel like a good solver, a puzzle comes along that humbles me. After several lookups and many trips to Ms. Check, I finally crawled to the finish, hair all sticking up and the rags of my clothes falling off.

I like a really hard puzzle, so thanks BEQ. I take my whipping as a challenge. Tomorrow's another day.

Great post!  There's another significant factor in the outrageous rise in housing (especially rentals):  wealthy foreigners (yes, especially Chinese) with plenty of cash allowed to purchase US real estate.  Sure, it sounds 'xenophobic' -- and it's true:  very few nations on earth allow foreign nationals to hold vast real estate holdings.  We do, and lower income American (no matter the age) are paying for it.  We need to change this, it's a 'global economy' only for the 1%!

Anyone watch Downton Abbey, read the biography of the Mitford sisters?  Everyone stayed in the main house or on a smaller house on the same estate.  And, of course, most of the servants "lived in."  So it is not just the people struggling financially who live together multigenerationally.  When I traveled in India two years ago and had the privilege of meeting many families from different walks of life, extended families living together or next door was common.  Even in the early days of this country it was common for several generations to live together.  Now, the attitude seems to be that we should throw the kids out and put granny in a nursing home on Medicaid after using up her money.

It's hard to believe that young people were the hardest hit in the recession.
It seems like people in their 50's and 60's were hard hit. Many who lost their jobs could not find work, even low paying jobs, (too old) had no health care insurance, yet had some health issues, went through their savings, and many lost their homes.

In regard to young adults, our legislators who have not attempted to give this age group a fairer shake to lessen school debt is hideous. They preach they are trying to make life better for everyone, but when they have the power to assist with educational fees/loans/interest and turn their back on it, it is shameful. Evidently they do not find their own kids struggling and/or they must not have struggled with college debt when they were young. Regardless they are not serving the young adults very well.

your kids should definitely help out financially, i bet they have cash for beer etc, decades ago--- only at 18 i earned about 135 a week gave 35 to my mother.
still had spending money.
boys paid for dates back then. if i could, your kids can.
Your wife"s rationale makes no sense? Maybe she is tired of cleaning up after other people. The longer adult children remain in the nest, the longer it will take them to reach adulthood.

Marilyn, you do realize that wages, especially at the lower end, are much lower than they used to be 30 years ago? you do realize that tuition and books are many times what they were when you were a student (with much lower inflation adjusted wages)? If you could barely do it, how could they (even if they gave all th eir beer money!).

My 22 year old son, who is a pilot, graduated from college and plans to move back home end of this year and pursue an MBA at a local school. My daughter is 18, working and attending Community college. It's a small house but they are welcome as long as they continue with their education. I won't support a girlfriend or boyfriend in my house. For me, they can live at home as long as they are pursuing education, any education. My wife feels differently, she wants them out, on their own or paying rent, weird. Her rationale makes no sense. Learning self-reliance and independence by moving out? they are already independent and self-reliant. They are family. They're still our kids. I left home early, went to college, got a trade and a profession, worked and never moved back with my parents, she did, too. It doesn't mean we have to demand the same thing of our kids.

Home sales at an all time low?   When college graduates have monthly loan repayments higher than a mortgage payment on many people's 1st time home, how can we expect these grads to save enough for a down payment on a home?

Not all millennials living at home are coddled moochers. In my experience they are responsible people with more than a modicum of independence. It may be an older tradition but it works for many families. Obviously your family is different.

And we may also find that older people may be receiving financial assistance from their children, and both may increase as the squeeze on young and old increases in this time of low pay, few benefits, and crummy jobs.

Yea, the recession or crushing loan debt has nothing to do with it; my student loan debt is currently $210,000 for Medical School and accrued interest while in school due to congressional end of subsidized federal graduate loans.  Also, helicopter parents and spoiled children never existed before Millennials came of age.  You make a lot of sense!

Actually, the American Dream was found to be too expensive for most US industry and they got paid a big bonus by US and Foreign governments to move entire operations to the Third World. If this were China, Finland, Greece or Germany, the companies doing such things would find themselves in hot water very fast.  I wish I knew how Europe remains European while the US is repeatedly taken over by new immigrant groups.

Chalk it up to student debt, more student debt, and fewer jobs in the fields requiring a college education, which then translates to underemployment. And who can buy a house these days?

When home prices average $100K and incomes average $45K with student loans fully paid, young people will start buying hoses. And why else are they living with parents? Their parents have taught them it's better to own your own home, rather than rent. Therefore, parents would rather house their adult children until they qualify for a mortgage or inherit the house.

Blame it all on the greed of home sellers, builders, and anyone else who has the means to exploit the middle-income and lower-income echelons. What a country this is.......top 1% earners hold 90% of the wealth. That IS the problem.

As somebody currently paying out of pocket full price for college, including some borrowing with full interest, because I had the gall to work and save a bit before going to school, I kind of resent the idea of mass debt forgiveness for student loans. I'm all for lower tuition with taxes and even free tuition one day for public schools, but if you sign on the dotted line and agree to repay a certain amount, why is it okay to just walk away from that because you feel like you don't want to pay it back anymore or because "Germany has free college why should I have to pay my debts?"

Usually those with the largest student loan balances, upwards of $80,000, wanted to go to the big out of state university right out of HS without slumming it at the local CC for a while for vanity, or chose to go private for the perceived prestige. I'm sorry, I have little sympathy for these people, especially considering they have an education which makes them much more employable than the average person.

As an engineering professor, you should know that your counterparts in financial engineering do not simply pull insurance premiums out of a hat or from the "what number do you want it to be" box. Even healthy young people who are top athletes can have potentially high medical costs, because auto insurers do not pay the medical costs for the at-fault driver in the event of an accident. Health insurers pay those costs, that start at the cost of an emergency room visit, which can be thousands, and, because of the ACA, now have no limit, and younger people are more likely to be that person. Athletic people may be healthier overall, but they are also more likely to sustain injuries from athletic activities. Lastly, anyone can have a serious illness.

As for insurance companies finding a way to "weasel out of paying" medical bills, I would guess that the weaseling, which continues with the government mandating the offering of so-called bronze plans, would be more on the part of those who do not want to pay premiums sufficient to fund a plan that would pay nearly all of their medical costs. To be fair, the NYT has also featured articles about patients being grossly overbilled by healthcare providers' practice of allowing out-of-network providers to participate in a patients' care without that person's consent and insurers stepping up to protect their customers from the threat of financial ruin by paying a far larger portion of the bill than they would legally be required to cover.

Why not coming to germany for university in the first place ? It is free, for all, not just for germans.
We simply made some economic costs research and realized, that our overall economy greatly benefits from free university for all.
At the moment there are 4500 US-Students studying here, while 25000 Chinese are here.
http://www.bbc.com/news/magazine-32821678

As an engineering professor who teaches bright, hard-working, entrepreneurial American students, I've seen this dismal Boomerang phenomenon even among them. Why's it happening?
Short answer: US policy and government are corrupt, bought, bribed by corporate and banking interests and lobbyists that profit from students' debt.
Longer answer:
1. US Student loans. $1.3 trillion. No bankruptcy relief, with harsh and punitive terms. Even small loans balloon from penalties and fees. The $1.3 trillion will soon be $2 trillion.
2. Massive outsourcing of tech and STEM jobs, while importing captive cheap labor on the H-1B visa to gut wages and openings for even more jobs in the US. Thus even my top STEM grads start out in lousy shape.
3. Outrageous costs for things like health care and legal fees. My students tend to be healthy, many top athletes, yet they're slammed with high premiums and deductibles, and even the insured ones go bankrupt when ins cos. find a way to weasel out of paying medical bills (which the NYT has covered). Meanwhile legal fees for things like the ruinous US divorce "industry" (the most rapacious in the world) and starting a business ruin many entrepreneurs.

US grads return home for pure financial survival, while others simply emigrate. (Germany, France, Benelux, Nordics, Spain, much of east Asia and South America have free college and low-cost healthcare and childcare, taxes not higher than US.) To solve the problem-- get money out of the US electoral process!
Amen.  The kids are alright.  Let them be...

Embedded here is a key factoid that differentiates the current generation of parents of young adults from their parents (who were my parents),  "They're not fainting at the idea that you have sex" while you are unmarried.  For boomers, who came of age during and after the sexual revolution, that was a big, if unspoken, reason for moving out; our parents often did worse than faint if confronted with the fact that we were having premarital sex.   Other commenters have pointed out that looking back more generations moving out before marriage was not the norm; I would point out that marriage ages were generally lower then as well.  I would guess that a lot of these behavior changes could be attributed to generational attitudes about premarital sex.
Very well said.

Well, geez. It ain*t like when I was young, in the late *60s/early *70s, when one could afford an apt. in Queens or even Manhattan with one bedroom, under 300 bucks a month, on a salary of less than 5,000 dollars a year.xplain to me exactly why anyone should live with four roommates in a barely-legal three-bedroom apt. with a galley kitchen, and no hope of saving for better, when you can live with Mom and Dad and pay off your student debt in ten years instead of thirty. Theyre not fainting at the idea that you have sex, and they like seeing their adult child more than once every six months or a year.

Just because some of youo lived in roach-infested walk-ups with some really--uh--interesting people on the corner downstairs at all hours, and ate ramen noodles til your hair fell out, doesn't make you heroes. And if these kids end up helping to care lovingly for grandparents, or even parents, before they hit 30, then they*ll have made more meaningful contributions to the world than you did. Leave the kids alone.

Here we go again with this common rant from people who obviously are stuck in time. You must have walked both ways up hill to school in the snow storms even in Sept.

The world is a different place today. My college fees were $125 a semester. My rent was $150 a month and gas for my car was about $1 a gallon.

So Constance, as soon as you bring us all back to a more affordable world, students will gladly live on their own because we have this thing called the internet and cell phones so kids don't need to live at home to get guidance from their parents.

There are plenty of good paying jobs in what I called "the skilled trades" -- construction, plumbing, pipefitting, welding, etc. My stepson was a weak student, but he went into the Navy and buckled down -- got into a nuclear tech program -- served 7 years and then got a job in a nuclear power plant. Not one week of college, and he earns close to 6 figures at age 34. Fantastic benefits, too.

There are many paths to a good life. Unfortunately, you can access none of them by majoring in French Medieval Poetry, Basket Weaving or Gender Studies. Most people have no business being in college -- it is for those who are academically inclined. We went down a very wrong, costly path when we let the public education system demand that EVERY student be on a college track and that the "only good jobs" were those that required college degrees.

If you really saved, then maybe. Most people just use the extra money they save from not paying rent or a mortgage, to go out and party, buy expensive cellphones and clothing, go on lux vacations.

Also: your independence and dignity and autonomy have a value, too. Sometimes it has a greater value than even a house or condo.

And what the other millions of American graduates who also can't afford a home? Including STEM grads hit hard by student loans and the mass outsourcing of US jobs to cheap-labor countries like India or Philippines (or the recruitment of their workers on abusive, cheap labor H-1B visas)? Always fun to point one''s finger and act morally superior, isn't it John-Robert, rather than accepting the broader systemic problems in US society and policy (massive student loan and healthcare debt, falling wages, US jobs shipped overseas, high divorce and legal costs, a corrupt political class bought off by corporate and special interests, failing infrastructure) and actually doing something about them, isn't it?

Americans are grossly inefficient with how we spend our money. Striking out to live on your own is an American phenomenon from before globalization when were a richer nation. Most of the rest of the world's young adult continue to live with their parents into adulthood both because they are less wealthy and because it their culture don't try to sell them the American myth of independence.

After I graduated from college and got my first job, I continued to live with my parents and paid them rent for 3 years until I saved enough for 30% down payment of a home. Even after I bought my home, I brought in roommates until my mortgage was paid off. I estimate that the typical American pay 50%-60% of his/her lifetime income to make banks and landlords richer. I became independent, not so much from my parents, but rather from the shackles of landlords and banks.
I have boomerang parents. My mother has lived under my roof a lot longer than I ever lived with her.

You are absolutely correct. Watch the You Tube videos of pundits trying to get Bernie to play the game of character assassination of his rivals. He just won't go there for them. He talks about his policy ideas and nothing else. The press must be turning itself inside out looking for dirt on him. The worst they have come up with "socialist" and he calls himself that! Besides, what does "socialist" mean to a country that hasn't seen what they really mean - a communist - in decades. They are fighting with a term from the 1930s that sounds pretty good to the rest of us.

This essay contains no information about Mr. Corbyn.  It follows the playbook of the US media:  paint everyone and everything with broad, meaningless labels ("even more radical" than Bernie Sanders!) that tell people what to think without troubling their brains.  Never enter the pros, cons & ambiguities of  actual policy; simply declare what is politically or economically "possible" or "impossible."  Discuss political tactics and considerations as if they, rather than the free & open debate of public policy, were what we should consider.  The goal is apparently to preclude discussion, thought or democracy.
